activity_name: Subject + infinitive + object
activity_desc: John sings a song.

activity_name: Subject + to be (is
activity_desc: are) + present participle + object

activity_name: Subject + have/has been + present participle + object
activity_desc: She has finished the work

activity_name: Subject + past participle + object
activity_desc: John played football.

activity_name: Subject + was/were + present participle + object
activity_desc: He was driving a car.

activity_name: Subject + had + past participle + object
activity_desc: They had completed the assignment.

activity_name: Subject + will + infinitive + object
activity_desc: She will buy a car.

activity_name: Subject + will + have + infinitive + object
activity_desc: You will have started the job.

activity_name: Subject + am/is/are + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: A song is sung by John.

activity_name: Subject + am/is/are being + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: A letter is being written by Sheena.

activity_name: Subject + has been/have been + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: The work has been finished by her

activity_name: Subject + was/were + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: Football was played by me

activity_name: Subject + was/were being + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: A car was being driven by him.

activity_name: Subject + had been + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: The assignment had been completed by them.

activity_name: Subject + will be + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: A car will be bought by her.

activity_name: Subject + will have been + past participle + by + object
activity_desc: The job will have been started by you.

activity_name: Subject +always + verb + ext.
activity_type: If there is always in an affirmative sentence
activity_desc: never will be used for ever/always in negative sentence and verb /adjective/adverb will be opposite meaning.

activity_name: Subject + auxiliary verb + always + verb/ adjective/ adverb + ext. Subject + auxiliary verb + never + opposite verb/ adjective/ adverb + ext.
activity_type: If there is always in an affirmative sentence
activity_desc: never will be used for ever/always in negative sentence and verb /adjective/adverb will be opposite meaning.

activity_name: Subject + verb + too + adjective + to + verb + ext. Subject + verb + so + adjective + that + subject + can/ could + not + verb + ext.
activity_type: If there is present tense before too
activity_desc: ‘can’ will be used after that and if there is past tense before too

activity_name: Subject + verb + as + adjective + as + noun/ pronoun. Subject + auxiliary verb + not + verb + less + adjective + than + noun/ pronoun.
activity_type: In order to change an affirmative sentence having an auxiliary verb with a verb/ adjective/ adverb into a negative sentence
activity_desc: we should add not after the auxiliary verb and use the opposite meaning of verb/ adjective/ adverb in negative sentence.

activity_name: Subject + verb + ext. Subject + auxiliary verb to do + not + opposite verb + ext.
activity_type: If there is no auxiliary verb in an affirmative sentence
activity_desc: to do verb will be used as auxiliary verb to make it a negative sentence. After to do verb not will be added and the opposite meaning of verb will used there. This to do verb will be according to the tense of the verb of affirmative sentence.

activity_name: Subject + must + verb + ext.Subject + cannot but + verb + ext. Subject + cannot help + verb-ing + ext\r\n
activity_type: For making a negative sentence from an affirmative sentence having must
activity_desc: we have to use cannot but/cannot help for must. In this case

activity_name: Every + noun/ body/ one + verb + ext. There is no + noun/ body/ one + but + verb + ext.
activity_type: To change an affirmative sentence having every + noun/ body/ one into a negative sentence
activity_desc: we can use there is no for every

activity_name: As soon as + subject + verb (past)
activity_type: subject + verb(past) + ext. No sooner had + subject + verb(past participle) + than + subject + verb(past) + ext.
activity_desc: To change an affirmative sentence having as soon as with two clauses

activity_name: Only + subject + verb + ext. None but + subject + verb + ext.
activity_type: Here only is used before a person
activity_desc: but alone is used after the person word and auxiliary verb. For changing an affirmative sentence into a negative sentence where only is before a person or alone is after the person and auxiliary verb

activity_name: Subject + auxiliary verb + alone + ext.\r\nNone but + subject + auxiliary verb + ext.
activity_type: It will be applied when the subjective word is a person word i.e he/ she/ I/ you/ they/ we/ any proper noun.
activity_desc: Affirmative:- He was alone alive in the house.\r\nNegative:-None but he was alive in the house.\r\n

activity_name: Only + subject + verb + ext. Nothing but + subject + verb + ext.
activity_type: when only is used before an object/thing
activity_desc: nothing but will be put there to make a negative sentence from an affirmative sentence .

activity_name: Subject + verb + only + object + ext. Subject + verb + nothing but + object + ext.
activity_type: nothing but is used in negative sentence for only when there is an object/thing after only in  affirmative sentence.
activity_desc: NULL

activity_name: Subject + verb + only + number/age + ext. Subject + verb + not more / less than + number/age + ext.
activity_type: when only is used before number/ age
activity_desc: not more/less than will be used  in negative sentence for only in affirmative sentence.

activity_name: Subject + auxiliary verb + ext. auxiliary verb + nt + subject + ext.?
activity_type: If there is an auxiliary verb in the assertive sentence
activity_desc: nt added with the auxiliary verb and be placed before the subject in the interrogative sentence

activity_name: Subject + auxiliary verb + not + ext. auxiliary verb + subject + ext?
activity_type: If the assertive sentence is a negative sentence
activity_desc: the negative word will be deleted in interrogative sentence and then it will be started with only auxiliary verb.

activity_name: Subject + verb + ext. to do + nt + subject + verb + ext?
activity_type: if there is no auxiliary verb in the assertive sentence/affirmative sentence
activity_desc: to make it an interrogative sentence to do verb will be used as an auxiliary verb there and nt will have to add after the to do verb and to do with nt will be placed before the subject in the interrogative sentence.

activity_name: Subject + never + verb + ext. to do verb + subject + ever + verb + ext.?
activity_desc: Assertive:- I never drink tea. Interrogative:-Do I ever drink tea?\r\n

activity_name: subject + auxiliary verb + verb + nothing + ext. auxiliary verb + subject + verb + anything + ext.?
activity_desc: Assertive:- There was nothing to do. Interrogative:-Was there anything to do?

activity_name: everybody/ all/everyone + verb + ext. Who + to do verb + nt + verb + ext.?
activity_desc: Assertive:- Everybody hates a liar. Interrogative:-Who doesnt hate a liar?

activity_name: none/no one + auxiliary verb + ext. who + auxiliary verb + ext?. auxiliary verb + anyone + ext?.\r\n
activity_desc: Assertive:- None/No one can do this.\r\nInterrogative:-Who can do this? Can any one do this?\r\n
